questions.question: The human cerebral cortex is organized into six histological layers (I-VI). Which layer is the primary recipient of thalamocortical input in primary sensory cortices?
options: Layer I (molecular layer)
Layer IV (internal granular layer)
Layer V (internal pyramidal layer)
Layer VI (multiform/polymorphic layer)
questions.explanation: Layer IV (internal granular layer) is the primary target of thalamocortical afferents in primary sensory cortices (V1, S1, A1). Thalamic relay neurons (from the LGN for vision, VPM/VPL for somatosensory, MGN for auditory) send their axons primarily to layer IV, where they synapse on stellate (granule) cells and local interneurons. In primary visual cortex (V1), layer IV is subdivided into IVA, IVB, IVCalpha, and IVCbeta, with the magnocellular LGN pathway terminating in IVCalpha and the parvocellular pathway in IVCbeta. Layer IV then projects to layers II/III (supragranular), which project to other cortical areas (corticocortical connections). Layer V contains large pyramidal neurons that project subcortically (to brainstem, spinal cord, striatum). Layer VI projects back to the thalamus (corticothalamic feedback). This canonical circuit motif is modified in different cortical regions — motor cortex has a thin layer IV because it receives less sensory input.

questions.question: The blood-brain barrier (BBB) restricts passage of most molecules from blood into brain tissue. What is the cellular basis of the BBB?
options: Neurons lining blood vessels form a physical barrier
Brain capillary endothelial cells connected by continuous tight junctions, surrounded by astrocytic end-feet and pericytes, creating a highly selective permeability barrier
Oligodendrocytes wrap around blood vessels to create myelin-like insulation
Microglia phagocytose all foreign molecules entering the brain
questions.explanation: The BBB is formed by brain capillary endothelial cells that differ fundamentally from peripheral endothelial cells: (1) Continuous tight junctions (claudin-5, occludin, ZO-1) seal the paracellular space, preventing passive diffusion between cells. (2) Low rates of transcytosis (pinocytosis) compared to peripheral endothelium. (3) Expression of specific transporters: GLUT1 for glucose, LAT1 for amino acids, transferrin receptor for iron, and efflux transporters (P-glycoprotein/MDR1, BCRP) that pump out lipophilic molecules. (4) Astrocytic end-feet ensheath >99% of the capillary surface and release signals (VEGF, Shh, angiopoietin-1) that induce and maintain BBB properties. (5) Pericytes embedded in the capillary basement membrane regulate BBB integrity, capillary diameter, and immune surveillance. Only small lipophilic molecules (<400 Da, <8 hydrogen bonds) readily cross the BBB by passive diffusion (e.g., O2, CO2, ethanol, nicotine). This is a major challenge for CNS drug delivery.

questions.question: The hippocampus is critical for the formation of new declarative (explicit) memories. What is the classic trisynaptic circuit of the hippocampus?
options: Cortex → amygdala → hippocampus
Entorhinal cortex (layer II) → dentate gyrus (via perforant path) → CA3 (via mossy fibers) → CA1 (via Schaffer collaterals) → entorhinal cortex/subiculum
Thalamus → hippocampus → cortex → cerebellum
Hippocampus → striatum → cortex → thalamus
questions.explanation: The classic trisynaptic circuit is the primary excitatory pathway through the hippocampal formation: (1) Synapse 1 (Perforant path): Layer II neurons of the entorhinal cortex (EC) project via the perforant pathway to granule cells of the dentate gyrus (DG). The medial EC (spatial/grid cells) and lateral EC (object/context information) provide different types of input. (2) Synapse 2 (Mossy fibers): DG granule cells project via large mossy fiber boutons to CA3 pyramidal neurons. This is a powerful detonator synapse with very high release probability. (3) Synapse 3 (Schaffer collaterals): CA3 pyramidal neurons project via Schaffer collateral axons to CA1 pyramidal neurons. This synapse is the most-studied site for LTP. CA1 neurons then project to the subiculum and deep layers of EC (layer V), completing the loop. CA3 also has extensive recurrent collaterals (autoassociative network) important for pattern completion. There is also a direct EC→CA1 pathway (temporoammonic path) that bypasses the trisynaptic circuit.

questions.question: Patient H.M. (Henry Molaison) underwent bilateral medial temporal lobe resection to treat epilepsy. What was the most significant neurological consequence, and what did it reveal about memory systems?
options: H.M. lost all memories including childhood memories

H.M. developed severe anterograde amnesia (inability to form new declarative memories) while retaining most pre-surgical memories and the ability to form new procedural memories, demonstrating that the hippocampus is essential for consolidating declarative but not procedural memory
H.M. lost the ability to speak or understand language
H.M. developed uncontrollable seizures that were worse than before surgery
questions.explanation: H.M.'s case (surgery performed by William Scoville in 1953, studied extensively by Brenda Milner) is the most important case study in the neuroscience of memory. After bilateral removal of the medial temporal lobes (including hippocampus, amygdala, and surrounding cortex), H.M. developed profound anterograde amnesia — he could not form any new declarative (explicit) memories (episodic or semantic). His working memory was intact (he could hold information for seconds), and he retained most memories from before surgery (though with some retrograde amnesia for several years preceding surgery). Critically, H.M. could learn new motor skills (mirror tracing, pursuit rotor) and showed normal priming effects, demonstrating that procedural/implicit memory systems (involving the cerebellum, basal ganglia, and neocortex) are independent of the medial temporal lobe. This double dissociation established the modern framework of multiple memory systems and demonstrated that the hippocampus is essential for memory consolidation, not storage.

questions.question: The basal ganglia circuitry includes a 'direct pathway' and an 'indirect pathway' that have opposite effects on movement. How does the direct pathway facilitate movement?
options: The direct pathway excites the motor cortex directly through glutamatergic projections

In the direct pathway, cortical excitation of D1-receptor-expressing striatal medium spiny neurons causes GABAergic inhibition of the globus pallidus internus (GPi)/substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr), disinhibiting the thalamus, which then excites the motor cortex — facilitating movement
The direct pathway inhibits the cerebellum to release movement commands
The direct pathway activates spinal cord motor neurons directly
questions.explanation: The direct pathway is a double-inhibitory circuit that facilitates desired movements: (1) Cortex sends glutamatergic excitation to the striatum (caudate/putamen). (2) Striatal medium spiny neurons (MSNs) of the direct pathway express D1 dopamine receptors and project GABAergically to the GPi/SNr (output nuclei of basal ganglia). (3) GPi/SNr normally provides tonic GABAergic inhibition of the thalamus (VA/VL nuclei). (4) When direct pathway MSNs are activated, they inhibit GPi/SNr, releasing (disinhibiting) the thalamus from inhibition. (5) Disinhibited thalamus sends glutamatergic excitation to the motor cortex, facilitating movement. The indirect pathway (D2-expressing MSNs → external GP → STN → GPi/SNr) has the opposite effect — it increases GPi/SNr output and suppresses movement. Dopamine from the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) facilitates the direct pathway (via D1 excitation) and suppresses the indirect pathway (via D2 inhibition). In Parkinson's disease, dopamine loss causes underactivity of the direct pathway and overactivity of the indirect pathway, producing bradykinesia and rigidity.

questions.question: The autonomic nervous system (ANS) is divided into sympathetic and parasympathetic divisions. What neurotransmitter arrangement distinguishes sympathetic postganglionic neurons from parasympathetic postganglionic neurons?
options: Both divisions use acetylcholine at all synapses

Sympathetic postganglionic neurons release norepinephrine (with some exceptions like sweat glands using ACh), while parasympathetic postganglionic neurons release acetylcholine; both divisions use ACh at preganglionic synapses
Sympathetic neurons use glutamate and parasympathetic use GABA
The neurotransmitter depends on the target organ, not the division
questions.explanation: The ANS neurotransmitter organization follows a consistent pattern: All preganglionic neurons (both sympathetic and parasympathetic) release ACh at nicotinic receptors (nAChRs) on postganglionic neurons. The divisions diverge at postganglionic neurons: Sympathetic postganglionic neurons primarily release norepinephrine (NE) acting on adrenergic receptors (alpha1, alpha2, beta1, beta2, beta3) on target organs. Important exceptions: (1) Sympathetic neurons innervating sweat glands (eccrine) release ACh acting on muscarinic receptors; (2) Sympathetic chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla release epinephrine (80%) and norepinephrine (20%) into the bloodstream. Parasympathetic postganglionic neurons release ACh acting on muscarinic receptors (M1-M5) on target organs. The effects depend on receptor subtype: M3 on smooth muscle causes contraction (bronchi, gut); M2 on heart causes bradycardia; M3 on glands causes secretion. The 'fight-or-flight' (sympathetic) vs. 'rest-and-digest' (parasympathetic) distinction reflects these different neurotransmitter-receptor systems.

questions.question: Broca's area (left inferior frontal gyrus) and Wernicke's area (left superior temporal gyrus) are connected by the arcuate fasciculus. Damage to Broca's area produces which type of aphasia?
options: Fluent speech with impaired comprehension (receptive/Wernicke's aphasia)
Non-fluent, effortful speech with relatively preserved comprehension (expressive/Broca's aphasia)
Complete loss of all language abilities including reading and writing
Loss of the ability to repeat spoken words only (conduction aphasia)
questions.explanation: Broca's aphasia (expressive/motor/non-fluent aphasia) results from damage to Broca's area (Brodmann areas 44 and 45) in the left inferior frontal gyrus. Characteristics: (1) Speech output is non-fluent, effortful, halting, and agrammatic (telegram-style, with loss of function words and grammar but retention of content words). (2) Comprehension is relatively preserved (patients understand spoken and written language reasonably well, especially for simple sentences). (3) Repetition is impaired. (4) Patients are typically aware of their deficit and frustrated. In contrast, Wernicke's aphasia (receptive/sensory/fluent aphasia) from damage to Wernicke's area produces fluent but meaningless speech (word salad, neologisms, paraphasias) with severely impaired comprehension. Conduction aphasia from arcuate fasciculus damage produces fluent speech with good comprehension but impaired repetition. The classic Wernicke-Geschwind model, while oversimplified, remains a useful framework. Modern neuroimaging shows that language involves distributed networks beyond these classical areas.

questions.question: The cerebellum receives two major excitatory inputs: mossy fibers and climbing fibers. What is the computational role of the climbing fiber input from the inferior olive?
options: Climbing fibers carry sensory information for real-time motor control

Each climbing fiber wraps around a single Purkinje cell dendrite and generates a powerful all-or-none 'complex spike'; climbing fiber activation signals motor errors and drives long-term depression (LTD) at parallel fiber-Purkinje cell synapses, providing the 'teaching signal' for motor learning
Climbing fibers excite granule cells to modulate mossy fiber input
Climbing fibers inhibit Purkinje cells to increase cerebellar output
questions.explanation: The climbing fiber (CF) system from the inferior olive is unique in neural circuitry: each CF contacts a single Purkinje cell (PC) with ~300-500 synaptic contacts wrapping around the proximal dendrite, creating the most powerful synapse in the brain — a single CF activation reliably triggers a 'complex spike' (initial Na+ spike followed by Ca2+ dendritic spikes and a burst of spikelets). The Marr-Albus-Ito model proposes that CFs carry error signals: when a movement produces an unexpected outcome, the resulting CF activation provides a teaching signal that induces LTD at simultaneously active parallel fiber (PF) → PC synapses. LTD weakens the PF synapses that contributed to the erroneous motor command, adjusting the cerebellar output for future movements. This cerebellar LTD requires simultaneous PF activation (via mGluR1/PKC signaling) and CF activation (via dendritic Ca2+ spikes). The result is supervised motor learning: the cerebellum progressively improves motor performance by reducing the discrepancy between intended and actual movements.

questions.question: The reticular activating system (RAS) in the brainstem regulates wakefulness and arousal. Which neurotransmitter systems contribute to the ascending arousal system?
options: Only acetylcholine from the basal forebrain

Multiple parallel systems: cholinergic (pedunculopontine/laterodorsal tegmental nuclei, basal forebrain), noradrenergic (locus coeruleus), serotonergic (raphe nuclei), dopaminergic (VTA), histaminergic (tuberomammillary nucleus), and orexin/hypocretin (lateral hypothalamus)
Only glutamate from the thalamus
Only GABA from the substantia nigra
questions.explanation: The ascending arousal system is a collection of parallel, largely redundant neurotransmitter pathways that maintain wakefulness and cortical activation. Key components: (1) Cholinergic: PPT/LDT nuclei in the brainstem activate the thalamus; basal forebrain (nucleus basalis) directly activates the cortex. Active during wake and REM sleep. (2) Noradrenergic: Locus coeruleus (LC) broadly innervates the cortex. Active during wake, reduced in sleep, silent in REM. (3) Serotonergic: Dorsal and median raphe nuclei project widely. Active during wake, reduced in sleep, silent in REM. (4) Dopaminergic: VTA projections to cortex and limbic areas promote wakefulness. (5) Histaminergic: Tuberomammillary nucleus (TMN) projects diffusely. Active only during wake (antihistamines cause drowsiness). (6) Orexin/Hypocretin: Lateral hypothalamic neurons stabilize the wake state by exciting all other arousal centers. Loss of orexin neurons causes narcolepsy with cataplexy. Sleep is actively promoted by GABA/galanin neurons in the VLPO (ventrolateral preoptic area) that inhibit arousal centers — the 'flip-flop' switch model (Saper).

questions.question: The somatosensory cortex (S1) contains a topographic map of the body surface called the somatosensory homunculus. Why is the homunculus distorted, with disproportionately large representation of hands and face?
options: The hands and face are physically larger than other body parts
The cortical area devoted to each body region is proportional to the density of sensory innervation and the behavioral importance of that region for fine discrimination, not its physical size
The distortion is an artifact of mapping techniques
All body parts have equal cortical representation
questions.explanation: The somatosensory homunculus (mapped by Wilder Penfield using electrical stimulation during surgery in the 1930s-50s) is distorted because cortical representation is proportional to: (1) Receptor density: The fingertips have ~2,500 Meissner's corpuscles per cm² and very small receptive fields (~2-3 mm two-point discrimination), providing high spatial resolution. The back has much lower receptor density and larger receptive fields (~40 mm discrimination). (2) Behavioral importance: Regions crucial for fine sensory discrimination (hands for manipulation, lips/tongue for speech and eating, genitalia) receive disproportionately large cortical representation, reflecting the neural resources required for processing. This principle of 'magnification factor' also applies to the visual cortex (the fovea, with highest acuity, is hugely overrepresented) and auditory cortex (frequencies important for speech are overrepresented). Cortical maps are plastic — amputation causes expansion of adjacent representations into the deprived area, and extensive training (musicians, Braille readers) expands the representation of trained fingers.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about the thalamus:
S1: The thalamus serves as the major relay station for sensory information (except olfaction) to the cerebral cortex.
S2: The lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) relays visual information from the retina to the primary visual cortex (V1).
S3: The thalamus passively relays sensory information without any processing or modulation.
S4: The reticular nucleus of the thalamus is a thin shell of GABAergic neurons that regulates thalamocortical activity and contributes to sleep spindle generation.
options: TTFT
TTTT
TFTT
TTTF
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: The thalamus is the obligatory relay for virtually all sensory modalities reaching the cortex: LGN (vision), MGN (auditory), VPM/VPL (somatosensory), and VP (taste). Olfaction is the notable exception — olfactory bulb projects directly to piriform cortex without thalamic relay (though olfactory information does reach the thalamus indirectly via MDN). S2 is TRUE: Retinal ganglion cell axons travel via the optic nerve, partially cross at the optic chiasm, and project to the LGN. LGN relay neurons project to layer IV of V1 via the optic radiations. The LGN has six layers: magnocellular (1-2), parvocellular (3-6), and koniocellular (between layers). S3 is FALSE: The thalamus is NOT a passive relay. Thalamocortical relay neurons receive massive feedback from the cortex (layer VI corticothalamic projections), modulatory input from the reticular nucleus and brainstem, and their firing mode (tonic vs. burst) is dynamically regulated. Only ~5-10% of synapses on relay neurons come from sensory afferents. S4 is TRUE: The thalamic reticular nucleus (TRN) is a thin GABAergic shell that receives collaterals from both thalamocortical and corticothalamic axons and provides inhibitory feedback to relay nuclei. TRN-thalamocortical interactions generate sleep spindles (11-15 Hz oscillations during stage 2 NREM sleep).

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about the hypothalamus:
S1: The hypothalamus controls body temperature, hunger, thirst, circadian rhythms, and autonomic nervous system function.
S2: The suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) is the master circadian clock, containing neurons with autonomous ~24-hour oscillations driven by transcription-translation feedback loops (CLOCK/BMAL1, PER/CRY).
S3: The hypothalamus has no connection to the pituitary gland.
S4: Orexin (hypocretin) neurons in the lateral hypothalamus regulate wakefulness and appetite, and their loss causes narcolepsy.
options: TTFT
TTTF
TFTT
TTTT
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: The hypothalamus is the master regulator of homeostasis and autonomic function, containing numerous specialized nuclei: preoptic area (thermoregulation), arcuate nucleus (feeding via NPY/AgRP and POMC neurons), lateral hypothalamus (feeding/wakefulness), paraventricular nucleus (autonomic control, CRH/AVP secretion), supraoptic nucleus (AVP/oxytocin secretion), ventromedial hypothalamus (satiety, defensive behavior), SCN (circadian clock), and others. S2 is TRUE: The SCN contains ~20,000 neurons that generate circadian rhythms through interlocking transcription-translation feedback loops: CLOCK:BMAL1 heterodimers activate PER and CRY transcription; PER:CRY complexes inhibit CLOCK:BMAL1, creating ~24-hour oscillations. Light entrainment occurs via melanopsin-expressing retinal ganglion cells → retinohypothalamic tract → SCN. S3 is FALSE: The hypothalamus has EXTENSIVE connections to the pituitary gland: the hypothalamic-hypophyseal portal system carries releasing/inhibiting hormones to the anterior pituitary; magnocellular neurons project axons directly to the posterior pituitary for oxytocin and vasopressin release. S4 is TRUE: Lateral hypothalamic orexin neurons promote wakefulness by exciting LC, raphe, TMN, and cholinergic nuclei. Autoimmune destruction of orexin neurons causes narcolepsy type 1 (with cataplexy).

questions.question: A patient presents with loss of pain and temperature sensation on the left side of the body below the neck, combined with loss of proprioception and fine touch on the right side below the neck, and right-sided motor paralysis. Based on these crossed sensory deficits, where is the lesion?
options: Left cerebral cortex

Right side of the spinal cord (Brown-Sequard syndrome — hemisection), because the spinothalamic tract crosses at the spinal level (contralateral pain/temp loss) while the dorsal column-medial lemniscal pathway and corticospinal tract cross in the brainstem/pyramids (ipsilateral proprioception loss and motor paralysis)
Left thalamus
Bilateral peripheral nerve damage
questions.explanation: This presentation is classic Brown-Sequard syndrome, caused by hemisection of the spinal cord (right side in this case). The crossed deficits arise because different pathways cross at different levels: (1) Spinothalamic tract (pain/temperature): First-order neurons enter the spinal cord and synapse on second-order neurons in the dorsal horn, which immediately cross to the contralateral side and ascend in the anterolateral system. A right-sided lesion interrupts ascending spinothalamic fibers that have ALREADY crossed from the left side, causing LEFT-sided pain/temperature loss. (2) Dorsal column-medial lemniscus (proprioception/fine touch): First-order neurons ascend ipsilaterally in the dorsal columns (gracile and cuneate fasciculi) and cross in the medulla. A right-sided cord lesion interrupts ascending ipsilateral dorsal column fibers, causing RIGHT-sided proprioception loss. (3) Corticospinal tract: Upper motor neuron axons cross in the pyramidal decussation (medulla) and descend in the lateral corticospinal tract. A right-sided lesion interrupts descending (already crossed) fibers, causing RIGHT-sided (ipsilateral) motor paralysis.

questions.question: Functional MRI (fMRI) measures the BOLD (blood-oxygen-level dependent) signal as an indirect measure of neural activity. A researcher shows subjects pictures of faces and houses while recording fMRI. Faces preferentially activate a region in the fusiform gyrus (fusiform face area, FFA), while houses preferentially activate a region in the parahippocampal gyrus (parahippocampal place area, PPA). What does this double dissociation demonstrate?
options: The entire visual cortex responds identically to all visual stimuli
Different categories of visual stimuli are processed by distinct, specialized cortical regions, supporting the concept of modular functional organization in the visual ventral stream ('what' pathway)
fMRI cannot distinguish between different types of neural activity
Face and house recognition use the same neural circuits
questions.explanation: This experiment (building on work by Nancy Kanwisher and others) demonstrates category-selective cortical modules in the ventral visual stream (the 'what' pathway from V1 through V2, V4, to inferior temporal cortex). The FFA (fusiform face area) shows preferential activation for faces compared to other objects, consistent with a dedicated face-processing module. The PPA (parahippocampal place area) shows preferential activation for places/scenes/buildings. This double dissociation (faces → FFA but not PPA; houses → PPA but not FFA) provides strong evidence for modular organization — different cortical areas specialize in recognizing different object categories. Other category-selective regions include the extrastriate body area (EBA, for bodies) and visual word form area (VWFA, for written words). Prosopagnosia (face blindness) from FFA damage provides converging lesion evidence. The degree to which this organization is innate versus experience-dependent is debated — the FFA develops by ~4-5 years of age and its development requires face exposure.

questions.question: To determine whether the amygdala is necessary for fear conditioning (associating a tone with a foot shock), a researcher needs to inactivate the amygdala during learning and test for the conditioned response. Which modern approach provides the most temporally precise and reversible inactivation?
options: Permanent electrolytic lesion of the amygdala before training

Chemogenetic silencing using DREADDs (Designer Receptors Exclusively Activated by Designer Drugs): express hM4Di (inhibitory DREADD) in amygdala neurons and administer CNO/deschloroclozapine 30 minutes before training to reversibly silence the amygdala, then test the conditioned response after the drug has cleared
Apply a permanent neurotoxin to destroy amygdala neurons
Remove the entire temporal lobe including the amygdala
questions.explanation: DREADDs (chemogenetics) provide reversible, cell-type-specific neural silencing ideal for this experiment. hM4Di is an engineered muscarinic receptor (Gi-coupled) that is insensitive to ACh but activated by the otherwise pharmacologically inert ligand CNO (or the more specific agonist deschloroclozapine). When activated, hM4Di hyperpolarizes neurons through Gi/o signaling (activating GIRK channels, inhibiting Ca2+ channels, reducing cAMP). Experimental design: (1) Inject AAV-hSyn-hM4Di-mCherry into bilateral amygdala → 3 weeks for expression. (2) Training day: Administer CNO/DCZ 30 min before tone-shock pairing (amygdala silenced). (3) Test day (24 hours later, no drug): Present tone alone and measure freezing response. If amygdala is necessary for fear learning, animals should show reduced freezing compared to vehicle controls. (4) Control: Repeat with drug during testing only to distinguish learning vs. expression deficits. DREADDs advantages over lesions: reversible (can test same animal with and without silencing), cell-type specific (with Cre-dependent viruses), and temporally restricted to specific behavioral phases.

questions.question: The visual system processes information through two parallel pathways from the primary visual cortex (V1). What are these pathways and what do they process?
options: The sympathetic and parasympathetic visual pathways

The dorsal stream ('where/how' pathway to parietal cortex, processing spatial location and visually guided action) and the ventral stream ('what' pathway to temporal cortex, processing object identity and recognition)
The myelinated and unmyelinated visual pathways
The conscious and unconscious visual pathways
questions.explanation: The two-streams hypothesis (Ungerleider and Mishkin, 1982; modified by Milner and Goodale, 1992) describes two functionally distinct visual processing pathways from V1: (1) Dorsal stream: Flows from V1 → V2 → V3/V3A → MT/V5 (motion processing) → posterior parietal cortex (areas 7a, LIP, MIP, VIP). Processes spatial relationships, motion, depth, and guides visually directed actions (reaching, grasping, eye movements). Damage causes optic ataxia (inability to use visual information to guide hand movements) and hemispatial neglect. (2) Ventral stream: Flows from V1 → V2 → V4 (color, form) → inferior temporal cortex (IT, including FFA, PPA, VWFA). Processes object identity, color, shape, texture, and face/scene recognition. Damage causes visual agnosia (inability to recognize objects despite intact basic vision) and prosopagnosia (face blindness). The streams interact extensively — they are not completely independent. This organization parallels the magnocellular (dorsal) and parvocellular (ventral) channels from retina through LGN to V1.

questions.question: Parkinson's disease is characterized by motor symptoms including bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor. What is the primary neuropathological feature?
options: Degeneration of upper motor neurons in the motor cortex

Progressive loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc), reducing dopamine input to the dorsal striatum and disrupting basal ganglia circuit balance between direct and indirect pathways
Demyelination of corticospinal tract fibers
Loss of cerebellar Purkinje cells
questions.explanation: Parkinson's disease (PD) is caused by progressive degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc), which project to the dorsal striatum (caudate and putamen) via the nigrostriatal pathway. By the time motor symptoms appear, ~60-80% of SNc dopamine neurons have been lost. The pathological hallmark is alpha-synuclein-containing Lewy bodies in surviving neurons. Dopamine loss disrupts the balance between basal ganglia pathways: (1) Direct pathway (D1): Normally facilitated by dopamine; becomes underactive → reduced movement facilitation. (2) Indirect pathway (D2): Normally suppressed by dopamine; becomes overactive → excessive movement suppression. The net result is increased GPi/SNr output (increased thalamic inhibition), causing bradykinesia (slow movements), rigidity (increased muscle tone), and akinesia (difficulty initiating movements). Treatment with L-DOPA (the dopamine precursor that crosses the BBB) replenishes striatal dopamine. Deep brain stimulation of the subthalamic nucleus (STN) reduces indirect pathway overactivity. Non-motor symptoms (depression, sleep disorders, constipation, anosmia) often precede motor symptoms by years.

questions.question: Neural crest cells contribute extensively to the peripheral nervous system during embryonic development. Which structures of the nervous system are derived from neural crest cells?
options: Motor neurons of the spinal cord
Dorsal root ganglion neurons, sympathetic and parasympathetic ganglia neurons, enteric nervous system neurons, Schwann cells, and satellite glial cells
Oligodendrocytes and astrocytes of the CNS
Purkinje cells of the cerebellum
questions.explanation: Neural crest cells (NCCs) are a transient, multipotent cell population that delaminates from the dorsal neural tube during neurulation and migrates extensively throughout the embryo. In the nervous system, NCCs give rise to: (1) Sensory neurons: All dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neurons and cranial sensory ganglia (trigeminal, geniculate, petrosal, nodose — though some cranial ganglia also have placodal contributions). (2) Autonomic neurons: All sympathetic ganglia neurons, parasympathetic ganglia neurons, and adrenal medullary chromaffin cells. (3) Enteric nervous system: All neurons and glia of the myenteric and submucosal plexuses (~500 million neurons, sometimes called the 'second brain'). Hirschsprung's disease results from failure of NCC migration to the distal colon. (4) Peripheral glia: All Schwann cells (myelinating and non-myelinating) and satellite cells in ganglia. NCCs also contribute to non-neural structures: melanocytes, craniofacial bones/cartilage (frontonasal), cardiac outflow tract, and teeth. CNS neurons, astrocytes, and oligodendrocytes are derived from the neural tube, not neural crest.

questions.question: The limbic system includes structures involved in emotion, motivation, and memory. The amygdala plays a central role in fear processing. What is the essential circuit for fear conditioning (learning to associate a neutral stimulus with danger)?
options: Cortex → hippocampus → cerebellum → motor output

Sensory input (auditory cortex and thalamus) → lateral amygdala (association) → central amygdala (output) → hypothalamus and brainstem (autonomic and behavioral fear responses: freezing, increased heart rate, stress hormone release)
Spinal cord → thalamus → frontal cortex → amygdala
Amygdala → hippocampus → cortex → cerebellum
questions.explanation: The amygdala fear conditioning circuit (elucidated by Joseph LeDoux and others) processes threat information through a defined pathway: (1) Sensory input: Auditory CS (conditioned stimulus, e.g., tone) reaches the lateral amygdala (LA) via two routes — a fast, crude 'low road' directly from the auditory thalamus (MGN) and a slower, detailed 'high road' from the auditory cortex. (2) Association: In the LA, CS (tone) and US (foot shock) inputs converge on the same neurons. Repeated pairing strengthens CS→LA synapses via NMDA-dependent LTP, so the CS alone can activate LA neurons. (3) Output: LA projects to the central nucleus of the amygdala (CeA, the main output station). CeA projects to multiple targets mediating different fear responses: lateral hypothalamus (sympathetic activation, increased blood pressure, heart rate), PVN (HPA axis activation, cortisol release), periaqueductal gray (PAG, freezing behavior), and reticulopontine nucleus (startle reflex potentiation). (4) Extinction involves prefrontal cortex (infralimbic/vmPFC) → intercalated cells → CeA inhibition.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about the spinal cord:
S1: The spinal cord gray matter is organized into dorsal horns (sensory processing), ventral horns (motor neurons), and intermediate zone (interneurons, autonomic neurons).
S2: Alpha motor neurons in the ventral horn directly innervate extrafusal skeletal muscle fibers.
S3: The corticospinal tract (pyramidal tract) crosses (decussates) at the pyramids of the medulla, so the left motor cortex controls the right side of the body.
S4: All reflexes require processing by the cerebral cortex before a motor response can be generated.
options: TTTF
TTTT
TTFT
TFTT
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: The spinal cord gray matter (butterfly-shaped in cross-section) is organized into: dorsal horn (laminae I-VI, receiving sensory afferents and containing projection neurons and interneurons for pain, temperature, touch processing); ventral horn (lamina IX, containing alpha and gamma motor neurons organized somatotopically); and intermediate zone (lamina VII, containing interneurons, propriospinal neurons, and the intermediolateral cell column in thoracolumbar segments for sympathetic preganglionic neurons). S2 is TRUE: Alpha motor neurons are lower motor neurons whose cell bodies are in the ventral horn and whose axons exit via the ventral root to innervate extrafusal (force-generating) skeletal muscle fibers at neuromuscular junctions. Each alpha motor neuron plus all the muscle fibers it innervates constitutes a 'motor unit.' S3 is TRUE: About 85-90% of corticospinal tract fibers cross at the pyramidal decussation in the caudal medulla, forming the lateral corticospinal tract. This means left motor cortex controls right-sided voluntary movements. S4 is FALSE: Spinal reflexes (stretch reflex, withdrawal reflex, crossed extensor reflex) are processed entirely within the spinal cord without cortical involvement. They are fast, stereotyped, involuntary responses.

questions.question: EEG (electroencephalography) recordings show different patterns during different states of consciousness. During wakefulness, the EEG shows low-amplitude, high-frequency (beta, 13-30 Hz) activity. During deep NREM sleep (stage 3), the EEG shows high-amplitude, low-frequency (delta, 0.5-4 Hz) waves. What neural mechanism produces the synchronized delta waves during deep sleep?
options: Delta waves are artifacts from muscle movement during sleep

Thalamocortical relay neurons, relieved from arousal system input and hyperpolarized by the reticular nucleus, enter burst-firing mode driven by T-type Ca2+ channels, synchronizing large populations of cortical neurons into slow oscillations
Delta waves are produced by individual neurons firing at 0.5-4 Hz
The brainstem directly generates delta rhythms transmitted to the cortex
questions.explanation: Delta waves during deep NREM sleep arise from thalamocortical circuit dynamics. During wakefulness, arousal system neurotransmitters (ACh, NE, 5-HT, histamine) depolarize thalamocortical relay neurons, keeping them in tonic firing mode (faithful relay of sensory information). When arousal systems reduce their activity during sleep onset, thalamic relay neurons become progressively hyperpolarized. At hyperpolarized potentials (-65 to -75 mV), T-type Ca2+ channels (Cav3.1) deinactivate. Subsequent depolarization (from cortical feedback or intrinsic currents) triggers low-threshold Ca2+ spikes that produce burst firing patterns. The thalamic reticular nucleus (TRN), connected to relay neurons by inhibitory GABAergic synapses, creates rhythmic inhibition-rebound cycles that synchronize thalamic bursting. These synchronized thalamic bursts drive large populations of cortical neurons to fire synchronously, producing the high-amplitude, low-frequency EEG patterns characteristic of deep sleep (delta waves at 0.5-4 Hz, spindles at 11-15 Hz). The cortical slow oscillation (<1 Hz) also contributes by alternating between UP states (active) and DOWN states (silent).

questions.question: To map which brain regions are activated during a cognitive task (e.g., mental arithmetic), a researcher uses fMRI. What is the key comparison needed to identify task-specific activations?
options: Compare brain activity during the task with no baseline measurement

Compare BOLD signal during the cognitive task with a carefully matched control condition that involves all the same sensory and motor components but lacks the specific cognitive operation of interest (subtraction method), to isolate brain regions specifically engaged by the mental arithmetic
Compare the subject's brain structure with a healthy control
Measure brain activity only after the task is completed
questions.explanation: The cognitive subtraction method (developed by Donders in the 1860s for reaction time, adapted for neuroimaging) is fundamental to fMRI experimental design. The principle: to isolate brain activity specific to a cognitive process, subtract the activation pattern during a control task from the activation during the experimental task. Both tasks should be identical except for the process of interest. For mental arithmetic: Experimental condition: '8 + 5 = ?' (requires numerical processing, addition, comparison). Control condition: 'XXXX' (visual fixation/passive viewing, controlling for visual input, motor response, attention). Better control: present the same digits without arithmetic ('8, 5 = XX', controlling for number perception). Subtracting control from experimental reveals regions specifically engaged in arithmetic (intraparietal sulcus, prefrontal cortex) while removing regions engaged in visual processing, motor planning, etc. Modern fMRI uses block designs, event-related designs, and sophisticated statistical analysis (general linear model, SPM). The BOLD signal reflects hemodynamic changes (increased blood flow and oxygenation) that lag behind neural activity by ~5-6 seconds.

questions.question: Place cells in the hippocampus (discovered by John O'Keefe, Nobel Prize 2014) fire when an animal is in a specific location in its environment. What complementary cell type was discovered in the entorhinal cortex by May-Britt and Edvard Moser?
options: Mirror neurons that fire during action observation
Grid cells that fire at regularly spaced locations forming a hexagonal pattern, providing a metric coordinate system for spatial navigation
Taste receptor cells that respond to specific flavors
Photoreceptor cells that detect ambient light levels
questions.explanation: Grid cells, discovered by the Mosers (Nobel Prize 2014, shared with O'Keefe), are neurons in the medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) that fire at multiple locations arranged in a remarkably regular hexagonal (triangular lattice) pattern as an animal moves through its environment. Grid cells are thought to provide a spatial metric — a coordinate system for distance and direction — that feeds into hippocampal place cells to construct the cognitive map. Key features: (1) Grid cells at different locations along the dorsoventral axis of MEC have different grid spacings (small grids dorsally, large ventrally). (2) Grid cells are organized into discrete modules with common spacing and orientation. (3) Other spatial cell types in the MEC include head direction cells (fire when the animal faces a specific direction), border/boundary cells (fire near environmental boundaries), and speed cells (firing rate proportional to running speed). Together, these cell types form a neural GPS system for spatial navigation and are thought to support episodic memory by providing the spatial context for experiences.

questions.question: The enteric nervous system (ENS) is often called the 'second brain.' What makes the ENS unique among divisions of the peripheral nervous system?
options: The ENS is located entirely within the brain

The ENS contains ~500 million neurons organized into two ganglionated plexuses (myenteric/Auerbach's and submucosal/Meissner's) within the gut wall, and can generate coordinated reflex activities (peristalsis, secretion) independently of CNS input
The ENS only responds to signals from the vagus nerve
The ENS has no neurons and consists only of smooth muscle cells
questions.explanation: The enteric nervous system is the largest and most complex division of the PNS, containing approximately 500 million neurons (more than the spinal cord) organized into two major plexuses within the gut wall: (1) Myenteric (Auerbach's) plexus: Located between the longitudinal and circular muscle layers, primarily controls gut motility (peristalsis, segmentation, migrating motor complex). (2) Submucosal (Meissner's) plexus: Located in the submucosa, primarily controls gut secretion, blood flow, and epithelial function. The ENS contains every class of neurotransmitter found in the CNS (serotonin — 95% of body 5-HT is in the gut — ACh, NO, VIP, substance P, etc.). Uniquely, the ENS can function autonomously: even if all extrinsic nerves (vagus, sympathetic) are severed, the gut maintains peristalsis and secretory reflexes. The ENS communicates with the CNS via the gut-brain axis (vagal afferents carry gut information to the brainstem). ENS dysfunction contributes to irritable bowel syndrome, inflammatory bowel disease, and Hirschsprung's disease (congenital absence of enteric ganglia due to failed neural crest cell migration).

questions.question: Cortical columns (also called cortical modules or hypercolumns) are fundamental units of cortical processing. In the primary visual cortex (V1), what is organized in a columnar fashion?
options: Color processing is organized in columns but orientation is not

Neurons within a column share similar orientation preference, ocular dominance, and spatial frequency tuning, creating a systematic map where a full set of orientation and eye-preference columns (a hypercolumn) represents a small region of visual space
All neurons in a column respond to the same object category
Columns contain only excitatory neurons with no inhibitory neurons
questions.explanation: In V1 (discovered by Hubel and Wiesel, Nobel Prize 1981), neurons are organized into radial columns (~500 um wide) sharing functional properties: (1) Orientation columns: All neurons from layers II-VI in a given column prefer the same orientation of a visual stimulus (horizontal, vertical, or oblique). Moving tangentially across the cortex, preferred orientation rotates smoothly, with occasional singularities (pinwheel centers). A full 180-degree rotation of orientations constitutes one orientation hypercolumn. (2) Ocular dominance columns: Alternating stripes (~0.5 mm wide) of neurons preferentially driven by the left or right eye, reflecting the segregated LGN input to layer IV. (3) Spatial frequency columns: Neurons within a column prefer similar spatial frequencies. (4) Color processing: Cytochrome oxidase-rich 'blobs' in layers II/III process color information. A hypercolumn (~1 mm²) contains a complete set of orientations for both eyes and represents approximately one degree of visual angle. Columns contain both excitatory pyramidal neurons and inhibitory interneurons (parvalbumin+, somatostatin+, VIP+) in a canonical microcircuit.
